question_details.query: What actions can be taken to increase plant species richness when restoring grassland habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: To increase plant species richness in grassland restoration, one replicated, controlled study in Germany found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix from a local source increased the species richness of target plants [3406]. Additionally, two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix led to an increase in the species richness of sown plants [3406]. One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that planting seedlings in addition to sowing seeds increased the number of plant species compared to sowing seeds alone [3399]. This study also found that this method increased the number of native plant species [3399]. Another replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that planting increased the species richness of forbs in 83% of cases and grasses in 50% of cases [3399]. Twenty studies found that restoring species-rich, semi-natural grassland resulted in increased plant species richness [133]. However, seven other studies found no clear effect on plant species richness from such restoration efforts, and three studies found that restored grasslands had a lower diversity and frequency of certain plant species [133]. Techniques that have been found to be effective for restoring species-rich grassland include grazing, introducing plant species, hay spreading, and mowing [133].

question_details.query: What are the potential negative impacts of different seeding strategies on existing native vegetation in North American grasslands?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that adding fertilizer after planting native prairie plants reduced the diameter of prairie lupine plants (3427). Three studies found that species richness was lower in sown areas than in nearby intact grasslands (3432). Three studies also found that while sowing native grass and forb seeds increased plant species richness during the first year, after 3–13 years, species richness did not differ between sown and unsown areas or was lower in sown areas (3432). One small American study found that species richness declined at one of two fields restored to grassland from croplands (361). Two studies found lower abundances of species on restored sites compared to unrestored sites, although one of these studies suggests that drought conditions may have confounded the results (361).

question_details.query: To ensure the successful establishment of sown species on a degraded site, what are the most effective site preparation and seeding techniques?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Six of seven studies, including five replicated, randomized, controlled studies, in Canada and Sweden found that ground preparation treatments increased the survival and growth rate of planted trees [1263]. One replicated study in Hungary found that sowing seeds in large gaps within vegetation led to a greater cover of sown target plant species than sowing in smaller gaps [3409].

question_details.query: Besides applying fertilizer, what alternative treatments or seeding methods can increase overall vegetation cover on arid, degraded land?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Sowing seeds at a higher density has been found to increase grass and forb cover (3405). In one study, sowing seeds at a higher density increased forb species richness (3405). Another study found that sowing seeds at a higher density increased the number of purple needlegrass seedlings (3405). However, in one study it did not alter the cover of sown plant species and in another it reduced the cover of native grassland shrubs (3405).

One study found that spraying a slurry of seed, mulch and water, also known as ‘hydroseeding’, increased overall plant cover in most cases (3412). Another study found that hydroseeding increased the abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding (3412). In one of two cases, hydroseeding also increased plant species richness (3412). However, another study found that hydroseeding did not alter vegetation cover (3412).

One study found that building artificial bird perches had no significant effect on seedling abundance (1817).

question_details.query: What is the available evidence on the effectiveness of using nurse plants to improve grassland plant community composition and richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study in France found that sowing seeds of nurse plants reduced the similarity of the plant community to that of a nearby intact steppe when compared to areas where no seeds were sown (3401). A replicated, controlled study in Slovenia found that sowing a seed mix containing nurse species resulted in a community composition that was less similar to the target community when compared to sowing a seed mix that did not contain nurse species (3402). In terms of species richness, the study in France found that sowing nurse plant seeds did not change plant species richness (3401), and the study in Slovenia also found no increase in species richness when using a seed mix with nurse species (3402). The study in France additionally reported that the richness was lower than in the nearby intact steppe (3401). Regarding abundance, a study in the USA found that sowing seeds of nurse plants alongside grassland species did not change grass or forb abundance (3402), and the study in France found no change in overall vegetation cover (3401). However, one study in Spain found that sowing seeds under nurse plants increased seed germination (3402). Furthermore, one of two studies in Kenya and Spain found that sowing seeds or planting under nurse plants increased the survival of planted plants, while the other study found only an initial increase in seedling survival with no difference after two to three years (3402).

question_details.query: What does the evidence suggest about the long-term effectiveness of grassland seeding projects for improving plant community composition and vegetation cover?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Sowing grassland seeds from a local source was found to increase plant species richness in one study (3400). In terms of vegetation cover, one study found that using local seeds led to an increase in vegetation cover over time, while another study reported no significant difference (3400). Sowing seeds from a local source, when combined with an increased number of species in the seed mix, was found to increase the cover of target plant species (3400). The timing of sowing also appears to be a factor; one study showed that sowing seeds in the spring resulted in higher plant diversity compared to autumn sowing (3407). Spring sowing was also found to increase the cover of sown grass and forb species (3407). When seeds were sown in only part of a site, one study observed an increase in plant species richness over time (3408). Additionally, new patches of sown plant species were recorded in unsown areas after partial seeding (3408). However, another study found that partial sowing did not alter the cover of sown grass and herb species (3408).

question_details.query: What interventions are available to enhance the germination or emergence of sown seeds during grassland restoration?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One of two replicated, controlled studies in the UK and Belgium found that removing vegetation before sowing seeds increased the germination rate of sown species (3416). The other study found that removing vegetation, along with removing leaf litter, before sowing seeds increased the number of seedlings for one of three species (3416). One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in Germany found that spraying with herbicide before sowing seeds increased seedling emergence for five of eight wildflower species (3418). One replicated, paired, controlled study in the USA found that sowing seeds in spring led to similar emergence of forb seedlings compared to sowing in winter (3407).

question_details.query: In the USA, which seeding techniques appear to be most effective for increasing the abundance of sown plant species?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Of two replicated, controlled studies in the USA, one found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix increased the cover of sown plant species, while the other found no change (3406). Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that increasing the number of species in a seed mix increased the species richness of sown plants (3406). One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that sowing seeds at a higher density did not alter the cover of sown species, but another replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that it increased grass and forb cover (3405). This second study also found that higher-density sowing increased forb species richness (3405). A site comparison study in the USA found that sowing grass seeds at a higher density reduced the cover of native grassland shrubs (3405). Finally, a replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that sowing seeds at a higher density increased the number of purple needlegrass seedlings (3405).

question_details.query: What are the different ways seeds can be introduced into a site to restore grassland vegetation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Different ways to introduce seeds for grassland vegetation restoration include slot/strip seeding, which can increase grass and forb species richness but has also resulted in failed introductions of sown species in the majority of cases (3411). Planting grassland plants, in addition to sowing seeds, has been found to increase the number of plant species compared to sowing seeds alone (3399). Grasslands can also be restored by seeding with various mixes, including complex or simple seed mixes, or through natural regeneration (3929).

question_details.query: Besides direct seeding of desired species, what sowing-based interventions can be used to modify grassland species composition?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Sowing seeds of nurse plants is one intervention. In one study, sowing seeds of nurse plants reduced the similarity of the plant community to that of nearby intact steppe when compared to areas where no seeds were sown (3401), while another study found that sowing a seed mix containing nurse species resulted in a community composition that was less similar to the target community when compared to a seed mix without nurse species (3402). Sowing nurse plants was also found to not increase species richness (3401, 3402). However, in one study, sowing seeds under nurse plants increased seed germination (3402).

Another intervention is to sow seeds at a higher density. One study found that this increased forb species richness (3405), while another found it did not increase the similarity of the vegetation community to that of the target community (3405). Sowing seeds at a higher density was also found to increase grass and forb cover in one study (3405) and reduce the cover of native grassland shrubs in another (3405). Furthermore, it was found to increase the cover of thickspike wheatgrass in one study (3405) and the number of purple needlegrass seedlings in another (3405).

question_details.query: To what extent does pre-seeding site preparation, such as removing vegetation or leaf litter, affect seed germination?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One of two studies found that removing vegetation before sowing seeds increased the germination rate of sown species (3416). The other study indicated that removing vegetation along with leaf litter increased the number of seedlings for one of three species (3416). The impact of removing leaf litter has shown mixed results (3414). Two of three studies revealed that removing leaf litter before sowing had varied effects on the number of seedlings of sown plant species (3414). Another study reported no change in the number of seedlings for two grass species (3414). Conversely, a study in Costa Rica observed that leaf litter removal led to a decrease in the density of new tree seedlings (1246). Additionally, removing topsoil or turf before planting was found to increase the survival of seedlings and plants in two studies (3415). In contrast, five of six studies identified that treating seeds with certain chemicals, such as potassium nitrate, nitric acid, and bleach, before sowing could increase the germination rate of herb seeds (3380).

question_details.query: What does the evidence from North America show about the impact of sowing grass seeds on native grass and forb abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from North America indicates that sowing grass seeds either reduced native grass cover or had no effect on native grass density in three out of four studies in the USA and Canada (3397). For native forb abundance, one study in the USA and Canada showed a reduction, while another found no change in density (3397). Furthermore, a study in the USA found that sowing grass seeds did not affect the cover or species richness of native plants (3397). In contrast, sowing native grass and forb seeds was found to have different effects. Two out of three studies in the USA found that this action increased the cover of grass species (3432), and three out of four studies in the USA found it increased the cover or density of forb species (3432). A separate study in the USA also reported that sowing native grass and forb seeds led to an increase in the cover of native plant species (3432).

question_details.query: For a degraded grassland site with dense existing vegetation, what are the documented outcomes of mechanical vegetation removal or soil disturbance techniques used prior to seeding?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two studies in Portugal and France showed that combining vegetation removal with mechanical soil disturbance led to an increase in the cover and diversity of understory plants (1274). One of these studies also noted a decrease in understory shrub cover (1274). Additionally, a study in France indicated that this combination of techniques increased the density of young trees (1274). In separate studies from the UK and Belgium, removing vegetation before seeding was found to increase the germination rate of sown species (3416). One of these studies also reported that removing both vegetation and leaf litter increased the number of seedlings for one of three species tested (3416).

question_details.query: What strategies related to the composition of a seed mix can be used to improve the outcomes of grassland restoration projects?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several strategies relating to the composition of seed mixes can be used to improve the outcomes of grassland restoration projects. One strategy is to increase the number of species in the seed mix, which has been found in some studies to increase the species richness of sown plants and the cover of target plant species (3406). However, other studies have found that increasing the number of species in the seed mix does not change plant species richness or the cover of sown species (3406). Another strategy is to include a mix of grasses, legumes, and other forbs, which can result in a higher species richness and abundance of butterflies compared to grass-only mixes (3929). Finally, the inclusion of nurse plants in the seed mix has been studied, with mixed results. While one study found that sowing seeds under nurse plants increased seed germination and survival, another found that a seed mix containing nurse species resulted in a community composition that was less similar to the target community and did not increase species richness (3402).

question_details.query: How do the effects of grassland sowing interventions change over time, based on available evidence?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Sowing grassland seeds from a local source can lead to an increase in vegetation cover over time, though the density of individual plants may decline (3400). In a German study, transplanted pepper saxifrage plants increased in number and spread to adjacent grassland, with 44% of new seedlings surviving over four months (3399). The timing of sowing also influences the outcome, as a study in the USA found that sowing seeds in spring increased plant diversity compared to autumn sowing (3407). Similarly, a UK study showed that spring sowing increased the number and cover of sown grass and forb species compared to autumn sowing (3407).

question_details.query: What site preparation methods are available to improve conditions for grassland seed germination or seedling survival?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two site preparation methods for improving grassland seed germination and seedling survival are sowing or planting nurse plants, and removing existing vegetation before seeding or planting [3402, 3416]. One study indicated that sowing seeds under nurse plants saw an increase in seed germination [3402]. In one of two studies, sowing seeds or planting under nurse plants increased the survival of the planted plants, while the other study found that while there was an initial increase in seedling survival, there was no difference in survival after two to three years [3402]. One of two studies revealed that the removal of vegetation prior to sowing seeds led to an increased germination rate of the sown species. The second study showed that removing vegetation and leaf litter before sowing resulted in a higher number of seedlings for one of three species [3416].

question_details.query: What are the effects of various post-seeding treatments, such as adding mulch, fertilizer, or using erosion blankets, on the overall abundance of vegetation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two of three studies found that using an erosion blanket after seeding and planting did not alter vegetation cover, while one study found that using an organic blanket after sowing seeds increased plant density (3431). Adding mulch before sowing seeds did not increase plant cover in one study, but another study found that it increased the cover of target plant species (3425). A study also found that adding mulch before sowing seeds increased the number of seedlings in most cases (3425). However, another study found that adding mulch before planting seedlings reduced the cover of planted species (3425). In the case of hydroseeding, which involves spraying a slurry of seed, mulch, and water, one of two studies found that it increased overall plant cover in most cases, while the other found that it did not alter vegetation cover (3412). Another study on hydroseeding found that it increased the abundance of half of the sown plant species compared to drill seeding (3412).

question_details.query: In European grassland restoration, what are the benefits and drawbacks of sowing non-native grass seeds versus seeds from a local source?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Sowing grassland seeds from a local source increased plant species richness when compared to a commercial seed mix in one study in Italy [3400]. A study in Germany found that using local seeds with more species in the mix increased the species richness of target plants [3400]. In one study in the USA and Germany, sowing local seeds increased vegetation cover over time compared to non-native seeds, but the density of individual plants decreased [3400]. Another study found no difference in vegetation cover between areas sown with local seeds and those with commercial seeds [3400]. The use of local seeds in Germany also led to an increase in the cover of target plant species and the abundance of one of four characteristic plant species that were sown [3400]. However, two studies in the USA and Italy found that sowing local seeds did not affect vegetation height compared to non-native or commercial seeds [3400]. Additionally, a study in the USA found that the survival of Sandberg bluegrass was not different when using seeds from a local source compared to non-local varieties [3400]. In a broader context, sowing grass seeds in general has been found to increase vegetation cover in two out of three studies in the USA, Iceland and Norway [3397]. However, three out of four studies in the UK, Hungary, Iceland and the USA found that sowing grass seeds either did not change or reduced overall plant species richness [3397]. A study in Hungary also reported that sowing grass seeds reduced the abundance of grassland species [3397].

question_details.query: Beyond simply sowing a standard seed mix, what alternative or additional actions can be taken to increase overall plant species richness in grassland restoration?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In addition to sowing seeds, planting seedlings has been shown to increase the number of plant species compared to sowing seeds alone [3399]. One study found that this approach increased the number of native plant species [3399], while another noted an increase in the species richness of forbs and grasses [3399]. Other effective techniques for restoring species-rich grassland, which has been found to increase plant species richness, include introducing plant species, hay spreading, and mowing [133]. Furthermore, while not an alternative to sowing, an additional measure is to increase the number of species within the seed mix. This has been found to increase the species richness of sown plants and, when using seeds from a local source, to increase the species richness of target plants [3406].
